stem: An 18-year-old with Type 1 Diabetes is admitted at 1400 with thirst, polyuria, and confusion. SBAR: Patient reports 3 days of increased thirst and urination. Alert and oriented to person only. Labs: Glucose 540 mg/dL, pH 7.22, HCO3 12 mEq/L, Ketones positive in urine. Complete the bowtie to plan the clinical management.

parameters.text: Monitor Serum Potassium and Anion Gap.

rationale.correct: The patient presents with classic signs and symptoms of DKA: hyperglycemia (540 mg/dL), metabolic acidosis (pH 7.22, HCO3 12 mEq/L), and ketonuria. The priority is to address dehydration and hyperglycemia. An initial bolus of 0.9% Normal Saline (action1) restores intravascular volume, improving perfusion and aiding in glucose excretion. A continuous Regular Insulin infusion (action2) is crucial to gradually lower blood glucose and correct the metabolic acidosis by inhibiting lipolysis and ketogenesis. Hourly blood glucose monitoring (param1) is essential to titrate the insulin infusion and prevent hypoglycemia. Monitoring serum potassium and anion gap (param2) is vital because insulin shifts potassium intracellularly, potentially causing hypokalemia, and the anion gap reflects the severity of metabolic acidosis.
rationale.incorrect: Starting 5% Dextrose with 0.45% NS immediately (action4) is contraindicated as it would further elevate blood glucose levels. Dextrose is added only when glucose levels fall below 250 mg/dL to prevent hypoglycemia. Subcutaneous Glargine (action3) is a long-acting insulin and is not appropriate for the acute management of DKA. Hemoglobin A1c (param4) reflects long-term glycemic control and is not useful in the acute setting. Weight and skin turgor (param3) are less sensitive indicators of hydration status compared to other parameters.
clinicalPearls: Always assess potassium levels before initiating insulin therapy in DKA. Hypokalemia can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias.
Monitor the anion gap to assess the effectiveness of treatment. A decreasing anion gap indicates resolution of metabolic acidosis.
Educate patients on sick day management, including the importance of monitoring blood glucose and ketone levels, and adjusting insulin doses as needed.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Even if initial potassium levels appear normal, total body potassium is often depleted in DKA due to osmotic diuresis. Insulin administration will further drive potassium intracellularly, potentially leading to severe hypokalemia. Proactive potassium replacement is often necessary.

mnemonic.title: DKA Treatment
mnemonic.expansion:
D: Dehydration - IV fluids (0.9% NS)
K: K+ - Monitor and replace potassium
A: Acidosis - Insulin infusion

reviewUnits.heading: Diabetic Ketoacidosis â€” Pathophysiology & Recognition
reviewUnits.body: DKA is a life-threatening complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and ketonemia. It primarily occurs in individuals with type 1 diabetes due to absolute insulin deficiency. The lack of insulin leads to increased lipolysis, resulting in the production of ketone bodies, which cause metabolic acidosis. Hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis, causing dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.

reviewUnits.heading: Testing Trap â€” Potassium depletion
reviewUnits.body: Even if initial potassium levels appear normal, total body potassium is often depleted in DKA due to osmotic diuresis. Insulin administration will further drive potassium intracellularly, potentially leading to severe hypokalemia. Proactive potassium replacement is often necessary.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Interventions for Diabetic Ketoacidosis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions for DKA include: 1. Fluid resuscitation with IV 0.9% Normal Saline to correct dehydration. 2. Insulin infusion to lower blood glucose and correct metabolic acidosis. 3. Electrolyte monitoring and replacement, particularly potassium. 4. Frequent monitoring of blood glucose, arterial blood gases, and anion gap. 5. Addressing the underlying cause of DKA, such as infection or missed insulin doses.
